--- title: "Directed Acyclic Graphs" author: "Yazan Dabbas" date: "12/17/2023" format: html: code-line-numbers: true df-print: paged --- ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_5fbe8ecdc52b72f1c1491ea226567092'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load Required Libraries library(tidyverse) library(dagitty) library(ggdag) ``` ::: **Draw DAG of Parking Spots Example ** ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_3696c78788adc8b30ddc93e84e49c58f'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Draw DAG for Sales Example sales_dag <- dagify( sales ~ parking_spots, sales ~ location, parking_spots ~ location, # location is the confounder labels = c( "sales" = "Sales", "parking_spots" = "Parking \n Spots", "location" = "Location" ) ) ggdag(sales_dag, use_labels = "label",text= FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](05_dag_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **Load the Data ** ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_414a1f556468de29343fa5e65485be87'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load the data customer_data <- readRDS('C:/Master Degree/Core Qualification_Compulsory Courses/Business/Causal_Data_Science/Data/Causal_Data_Science_Data/customer_sat.rds') # Be familiar with the data head(customer_data) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: **Regress `satisfaction` on `follow_ups` ** ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_488f259bf90725f85a74b28f640e696b'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Regress satisfaction on follow_ups ## Simple linear Regression ## model1 <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = customer_data) summary(model1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> #> Call: #> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = customer_data) #> #> Residuals: #> Min 1Q Median 3Q Max #> -12.412 -5.257 1.733 4.506 12.588 #> #> Coefficients: #> Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept) 78.8860 4.2717 18.467 1.04e-10 *** #> follow_ups -3.3093 0.6618 -5.001 0.000243 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #> #> Residual standard error: 7.923 on 13 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared: 0.658, Adjusted R-squared: 0.6316 #> F-statistic: 25.01 on 1 and 13 DF, p-value: 0.0002427 ``` ::: ::: **Regress `satisfaction` on `follow_ups` and account for `subscription` ** ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_b56d4f9bdea15b01731d0109d42c71c8'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Regress satisfaction on follow_ups and account for subscription ## Multiple Linear Regression model2 <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = customer_data) summary(model2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> #> Call: #> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = customer_data) #> #> Residuals: #> Min 1Q Median 3Q Max #> -4.3222 -2.1972 0.3167 2.2667 3.9944 #> #> Coefficients: #> Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept) 26.7667 6.6804 4.007 0.00206 ** #> follow_ups 2.1944 0.7795 2.815 0.01682 * #> subscriptionPremium 44.7222 5.6213 7.956 6.88e-06 *** #> subscriptionPremium+ 18.0722 2.1659 8.344 4.37e-06 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #> #> Residual standard error: 2.958 on 11 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared: 0.9597, Adjusted R-squared: 0.9487 #> F-statistic: 87.21 on 3 and 11 DF, p-value: 5.956e-08 ``` ::: ::: **Compare the coefficients and give explanations ** ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_14819f6919a0bea7b3f97bdb470326be'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Compare coefficients from the two models coef_comparison <- data.frame( Model = c("Model 1", "Model 2"), Intercept = c(coef(model1)[1], coef(model2)[1]), FollowUps = c(coef(model1)[2], coef(model2)[2]), PremiumPlus = c(0, coef(model2)[grep("subscriptionPremium\\+", names(coef(model2)))]), Elite = c(0, coef(model2)[grep("subscriptionElite", names(coef(model2)))]) ) print(coef_comparison) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> Model Intercept FollowUps PremiumPlus Elite #> Model 1 78.88605 -3.309302 0.00000 0 #> subscriptionPremium+ Model 2 26.76667 2.194444 18.07222 0 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-important appearance="minimal"} - **The baseline of `satisfaction` is lower in Model 2 because it has a lower intercept compared to Model 1.** - **Taking subscription levels into account changed the direction of the relationship between `FollowUps` and `satisfaction` (from negative impact into a positive one.** - **There is a positive impact on `PremiumPlus`, while no addition impact on the `Elite` subscription level.** ::: **Plot the Data ** ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_93f0db705be8a697815f04d20c2f2f41'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Plot the data ### Simpson's Paradox : Subscription is the Confounder ### ## Not conditioning on subscription simps_not_cond <- ggplot(customer_data, aes(x = follow_ups, y = satisfaction)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.8) + stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = F) + labs(title = "Relationship between Follow-ups and Satisfaction", x = "Follow-ups", y = "Satisfaction")+ theme_minimal() + theme(legend.position = "right") ## Conditioning on subscription simps_cond <- ggplot(customer_data, aes(x = follow_ups, y = satisfaction, color = subscription)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.8) + stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = F, size = 1) + labs(title = "Relationship between Follow-ups and Satisfaction by Subscription Level", x = "Follow-ups", y = "Satisfaction", color = "Subscription") + theme_minimal() + theme(legend.position = "right") simps_not_cond ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](05_dag_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} simps_cond ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](05_dag_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-2.png){width=672} ::: :::
